tweet: That’s why I’ve authored a common sense bill with @TimKaine that ensures Congress can oversee major trade policy decisions that so directly affect consumers, small businesses, farmers, and families all across the country. This isn’t a partisan issue. It's our job.

When trade talks go south, or his shortsighted border policies fail to garner results, or the news of the day is not to his liking, @realDonaldTrump resorts to tariffs that don't require congressional approval. Congress must have a say in the decisions that impact every American.

And there’s a lot at stake for Delawareans. According to @uscensusbureau, Delaware imported $183 million of goods from Mexico in 2017 and exported $327 million of goods. Trade with Mexico also supports 15,000 jobs in the First State. Those are big numbers for a small state.

Even @SenateGOP members are speaking out. According to @ChuckGrassley, “Trade policy and border security are separate issues. This is a misuse of presidential tariff authority and counter to congressional intent.”

New tariffs would be devastating for the auto industry, too. Take it from @auto_alliance: “[tariffs] are a tax on our customers, which means they’re harmful to our nation’s economy and the millions of American jobs that depend on cross-border trade" https://www.cnn.com/2019/05/31/business/mexico-tariffs-auto-industry/index.html …

.@USChamber puts it plainly: “$17 billion. That’s the potential tax increase that would be passed along to American businesses and consumers by a 5% tariff on important goods from Mexico” https://www.uschamber.com/series/above-the-fold/quick-take-your-primer-the-new-tariffs-mexico?utm_content=sf213628888&utm_medium=spredfast&utm_source=twitter&utm_campaign=U.S.%20Chamber%20of%20Commerce&sf213628888=1 …

The president of @NFTC, which represents our nation’s largest exporters, called Trump’s new threat of tariffs “a colossal blunder.” https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/30/us/politics/trump-mexico-tariffs.html …

.@realDonaldTrump’s trade war with China continues to hurt businesses and consumers and has already cost Americans over $25 billion according to @TariffsHurt. But his threat to impose new tariffs on Mexico is perhaps even more reckless. And you don’t have to take my word for it…

This comes almost exactly 2 years after @realdonaldtrump’s decision to abandon American leadership by withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement. Almost every policy issued since then takes us even further in this perilous direction. https://twitter.com/POLITICOPro/status/1134501541946114048 …

I want to thank Bob Mueller for completing yet another tour of duty for our nation. His work may be done, but he has now left it to Congress to ensure ‘that no person is above the law.’ We have an obligation to meet that responsibility as a co-equal branch of government.

Today, Bob Mueller reiterated what's been clear since the Special Counsel's report was released:

1. We need to address Russian interference in our elections

2. The President has not been exonerated

3. And Congress has a constitutional duty to be a check on executive power

Another approach is passing the #PFAS Action Act of 2019, a law I authored with @SenCapito to designate #PFAS as a hazardous substance eligible for cleanup under the #Superfund law
 https://environmentamerica.org/news/ame/bipartisan-pfas-action-act-would-solve-important-piece-toxic-puzzle …

One approach to addressing this concern lies in the #PFAS Release Disclosure Act authored by @SenCapito, which I cosponsored with @gillibrandny – to better inform the public when those chemicals are released into the environment https://www.wvpublic.org/post/capito-among-senators-seeking-faster-epa-action-pfas-chemical-pollution#stream/0 …

So it’s no surprise that many states are taking matters into their own hands and setting their own standards. Neither is it a surprise that many of us have concluded that federal legislation is needed to more urgently and decisively address #PFAS. https://www.mlive.com/news/2019/03/michigan-will-draft-pfas-standards-for-public-drinking-water.html …

Finally, @EPA weakened its draft guidance for cleaning up contaminated #PFAS sites following pressure from the @DeptofDefense. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/25/us/epa-chemical-standards-water.html …

Second, @EPAAWheeler refused to commit to setting a drinking water standard for #PFAS until public and Congressional outcry forced him to reverse course before he was confirmed. https://www.fosters.com/news/20190214/epas-pfas-plan-lacks-drinking-water-standards …

First, @EPA’s 2019 #PFAS Action Plan largely includes commitments to consider whether to regulate PFAS contamination, steps that Scott Pruitt announced almost a year earlier. https://www.politico.com/story/2019/02/14/epa-chemical-plan-1174120 …

Today EPW is examining a range of bills to combat #PFAS contamination. These persistent chemicals threaten the drinking water of millions – including families in Delaware. You'd think that this would lead the @EPA to respond with urgency. That has not been the case:

Our colleagues in industry often remind Congress that #PFAS chemicals are used in everything from medical devices to solar panels. 

That’s really not the point. 

We want PFAS chemicals to stay in the solar panels, and out of the drinking water.

I understand that the use of #PFAS in firefighting foam, for example, has supported our military readiness and saved lives. But the cruel irony is that when PFAS winds up in a glass on the kitchen table, those same chemicals can endanger lives.

A large NASA Convair jet had been cleared to land on the same runway and at the same time as a Navy P-3 aircraft. It took over an hour for firefighters to control the blaze. Later that day, we would learn that 16 people died, and only one crewman on the P-3 survived.

In 1973, I was a young naval flight officer stationed at Moffett Field Naval Air Station in California. As I drove to work on a sunny April morning, I could see a large black plume of smoke rising from the air station while still several miles away.

We’ve seen this movie before with @AmbJohnBolton at the helm, and I fear that the Trump Administration’s strategy could get us into another war. Too many U.S. soldiers lost their lives during wars in Vietnam and Iraq. We have got to be smarter than this.

In 2003, top elected officials – including the President and Vice President – alleged Iraq had developed weapons of mass destruction. The Iraq War was also predicated on a lie – perpetrated chiefly by Trump’s current national security advisor – and has claimed over 4,100 lives.
In the years between 1955-1975, 55,000 American soldiers lost their lives during the Vietnam War – colleagues I served alongside. That war was predicated on a lie.

As @realDonaldTrump ramps up his dangerous rhetoric and escalates tensions with Iran, it's important we never lose sight of the real costs of wars -- especially those predicated on a lie. https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1130207891049332737 …

Too many U.S. soldiers lost their lives during the Vietnam and Iraq wars. Why haven’t we learned from this? We should be prioritizing diplomacy. Not escalating tensions with Iran—and risking war and American lives—with no coherent strategy.

We’ve seen this movie before. And thanks to @AmbJohnBolton’s rash actions in the Middle East, I can see it happening again. 

I don’t want to see it happen again. I’ve been to too many funerals of service members from Delaware who died in Iraq. I don’t want to go to any more.

We had a similar situation in Iraq. The president, Vice President and their cabinet alleged weapons of mass destruction. From that allegation, the Iraq War was launched. 
 
That war has claimed 4,100 lives. It, too, was predicated on a lie, perpetrated chiefly by John Bolton. pic.twitter.com/frmyRf0SIR

Earlier this week, while out for a run about two miles from the U.S. Capitol, I passed by a granite wall engraved with 55,000 names of men and women killed during the Vietnam War. I served with them.

They died, and many of us risked our lives, over a war predicated on a lie. pic.twitter.com/DRYesc6JpY
